 To answer the original question, why was it okay for God to kill in the Bible when we are not allowed to do so?
 My best response is this: the God of the Old Testament behaves differently from the God of the New Testament (i.e. before Jesus and after Jesus). Not because God changed, but because we did. Our understanding of God, of the universe, and of ourselves naturally evolved and grew more complex over time. Think of a parent disciplining a young child versus disciplining an older one. In the earliest years, there is merely action and consequence, disobedience and punishment. We learn not to do something because something bad happens. When God intervened in the Old Testament, he was not taking lives merely for his own convenience; it was a punishment for sin (something that still exists in our own world in the form of the death penalty, though that is another can of worms which need not be opened here).
 
 However, as we grow and age, we gain understanding. We are taught that some acts are just inherently wrong, the punishing doesn't make them so. So where the Old Testament emphasized the letter of the law, the New Testament stresses the spirit of the law and makes possible mercy. We become responsible for understanding why things are wrong and, through Jesus, are able to make reparation for our sins. Heaven becomes attainable, but hell also becomes possible (in my opinion, a much more terrifying punishment than those in the OT).
 
 There is a great deal more theology that goes into this response, but I have explained it as best I understand it. I hope it helps!
